content: Many governments recognize the international risks posed by environmental degradation and climate change, leading to the negotiation of international agreements to protect the environment and promote sustainable growth. While industrialized countries are called upon to take the lead, it is acknowledged that efforts from wealthier nations alone may not be sufficient. Lower-income countries may lack the resources and expertise to implement environmental measures, making international financial assistance crucial. International financial assistance is crucial for lower-income countries to address global environmental problems, as they may lack the resources and expertise to implement protective measures on their own. The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) was the first treaty to address human-driven climate change, with higher-income Parties committing to provide support. The United States ratified the UNFCCC treaty in 1992, committing to provide financial resources for developing countries to comply with their climate change obligations. This assistance includes both financial and technical support through various programs. The United States has provided financial and technical assistance for climate change activities in developing countries through bilateral and multilateral programs, emphasizing the importance of burden sharing among developed country Parties. The United States has provided financial and technical assistance for climate change activities in developing countries through various international financial institutions and organizations, including the Global Environment Facility, the Green Climate Fund, and the World Bank's Climate Investment Funds. The Convention on Climate Change establishes a financial mechanism to provide funds to developing country Parties. The UNFCCC establishes a financial mechanism to provide climate finance to developing countries, with the GEF as an official operating entity. The relationship between the UNFCCC and the GEF is outlined in a memorandum of understanding. The US has supported the GEF since its establishment in 1991, making commitments to all six GEF resource replenishments. The US has supported the GEF since its establishment in 1991, making commitments to all six GEF resource replenishments totaling $2.732 billion. U.S. disbursements to the GEF since 1994 have totaled approximately $2.2 billion. In 2009, the COP to the UNFCCC in Copenhagen noted the Copenhagen Accord, and in 2010, the COP in Cancun officially adopted elements of the accord, including Fast start financing. In 2009, the COP to the UNFCCC in Copenhagen acknowledged the Copenhagen Accord, and in 2010, the COP in Cancun officially adopted elements of the accord, including Fast start financing with a commitment of $30 billion for 2010-2012 and a pledge to mobilize $100 billion per year by 2020 for climate finance needs of developing countries. The Paris Agreement acknowledges the pledge by developed countries to mobilize $100 billion per year by 2020 to address climate finance needs of developing countries. Funds can come from various sources, and the agreement emphasizes support for developing nations in combating climate change. The Paris Agreement builds upon the Convention by bringing all nations into a common framework to combat climate change and support developing countries. Developed countries, including the United States, are obligated to provide financial support for mitigation and adaptation efforts. The agreement encourages all Parties to voluntarily provide financial support, with developed countries taking the lead in mobilizing climate finance from various sources. The COP Decision to implement the Paris Agreement emphasizes the need for progression in climate finance efforts. Congressional committees overseeing international climate change assistance include the House Committees on Foreign Affairs, Financial Services, and Appropriations, and the Senate Committees on Foreign Relations and Appropriations.
